Award.AwardTitle: When Climate Changed: The Fall of Empires and the Rise of a New Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The history of modern climate science has generally been written as if the field had sprung to life quite suddenly, inexplicably, and in isolation in the post-war United States. Although it was not until the 1950s that computers were introduced to simulate the global circulation and satellites began to record atmospheric data, these were shifts in technology, not in the basic theories or methods of the field. In fact, the foundations of modern climate science emerged over the century before World War Two, as climate came to be understood in terms of the exchange of energy among systems at a spectrum of scales.

This project funded by the Science, Technology & Society Program focuses on the origins and development of concepts of scale in the atmospheric sciences. How did people begin to see that the familiar local weather patterns were dependent, at the smallest scale, on the transfer of energy among plants, water, air, and soil, while simultaneously embedded in far larger, ultimately planetary patterns of circulation? How did they recognize that the duration of atmospheric phenomena varies with spatial scale, making it possible to estimate the time scales on which to look for climate variations? This project argues that Europe's modern continental empires (Austro-Hungarian, Russian, Soviet, Prussian, and Nazi) provided a crucial context for these developments. These empires placed a premium on charting their own natural and human diversity. As scientific observers circulated within their borders, their attention was drawn to climatic "boundaries" and "transitional regions." Imperial scientists were charged with understanding both the factors determining the spatial differentiation of climate and the ways in which local climates participated in a continental regime of atmospheric circulation. Out of this context emerged the field of "dynamic climatology," with its characteristic attention to the composition and motion of air masses, bridging the disciplines of physics and geography and paving the way for computer modeling. At the same time, these empires served, to varying political ends, as laboratories for the study of the relationship between humans and their natural environments -- leading above all to the concept of the biosphere and to the science of bioclimatology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“When Climate Changed” is a history of concepts of scale in the atmospheric sciences in their relation to projects of empire. I argue that a new way of thinking about the relationship between local weather and the global atmosphere emerged in part from efforts to reimagine the space of the Habsburg empire. In the 19th c., in both the Habsburg and Romanov empires, naturalists divided and re-divided the imperial map into climatic zones, in order to arrive at a scientific understanding of the relationship between populations and land, with the aim of more efficiently exploiting each empire’s natural and human diversity. Romanov and Habsburg scientists were thus tasked with analyzing local differences within the larger, integrated context of the empire as a whole. They described the territory of each empire in terms of a shared vocabulary of “natural regions” and “transition zones.” I argue that climatology as a regionalizing science was naturally attuned to the interdependence of phenomena at multiple spatial scales as well as to the
variability of climate over time. It was thus in central and eastern Europe, in
the land empires of Austria and Russia before the First World War, that climate came to be understood in terms of the exchange of energy across scales, from the global scale to the scales of agriculture and human health. It was here that climate came to be seen as a process of exchange, as something that connects people, for better or worse, rather than sets them apart.

My project has three main goals. First, I hope to expand our sense of what climate science is. A broader historical view of the field emphasizes not the work of computer modeling, nor solely the mathematical analysis of the global circulation that paved the way for modeling. Instead, we find a science that has probed the significance of climate for human and non-human life; a science intent on integrating the global and human scales. Intriguingly, this is precisely the direction in which climate science is moving today: away from refining its global predictions, toward study of the human impact of climate change on regional and local scales.

Second, I hope to historicize the concepts of physical scale which we, as historians, often take for granted. I want to show how Central Europeans, both expert and lay, situated themselves with respect to the shifting horizons of the 19th century, in part through an engagement with the earth sciences--whether they were tracking weather patterns, seasonal changes,or seismic waves.

And third, I hope to contribute to the historiography of science and empire: I see this as a step toward building a historical typology of empires that takes knowledge-making practices into account. My research suggests both how Habsburg governance shaped scientific practice, and how scientific images shaped the imaginations of Habsburg subjects.
